body:
Being a fresher as a web developer this course helped me not only to understand web coding in such a easy way but also made each section of the course interesting and enjoyable due to the awesome teaching method by 'Colt Steele'.

Best course to start with as a beginner into Web Development!!!

Great course while studying computer science students during summer vacation and I enjoyed each part of the course. Whoever is having passion for web development must pursue this course for having better knowledge about front and back end development.

Very comprehensive overall. Can be a bit difficult to follow due to the speed the course progresses through all the content, but other than that, I cannot ask for more. Definitely going to check out the advanced course :D

good introduction course for web development. Course cover various of web dev essentials such as html, css, javascript, nodejs, api , routes etc. Great support from the TA.

However, the course is rather outdated and lots of technology is no longer support / use nowadays such as bootstrap 3 and jQuery, Javascript ES 5 only . Also lots of coding in backend and the tools are also out of date. It makes the TA keeps updating materials, new videos as a supplement to cover those parts and its a bit messy.

I enjoy the course as Colt is really good at teaching. But I personally would not recommend this course simply because the outdated content. It is a course 5 years ago and I end up need to subscribe different courses to supplement those parts.

I hope Colt and the team will revisit my comment and consider to update most of the content in the course include ES6 Javascript syntax, backend sessions etc.

Not as good as expected. Some of the materials are old and you get a feeling you´ll have to update yourself. The course needs a revamp to make it a 2020 course.

There are a lot of intermediate comments made by Colt´s assistant Ian that try to help but reflect the fact the course needs to be reviewed. I know that is a lot of work, but that would get you 5 star reviews.

On the other hand I feel disappointed with the fact that in the end, I wasn´t thought how to create my own website. The deployment part speaks briefly about how to deploy a project in Heroku. Nothing is said about what about if I already have my own website. Or if I want to create a new one. I wanted to learn coding to improve my business website. I have it in wordpress. I'm aware the backend language is php and I can use a control panel to manage it. Nothing in the course is said about this.

Some of the contents are disconnected. At some point you'll be sent to Ian's youtube videos, then comes Ellie to speak about javascript more advanced issues, not announced.

I got to the end and the YelpCamp project that was core to our learning through experience was incomplete. They give you a number of videos from youtube to try and give you the essentials. I only watched one by Ian on google maps, and it was so old I couldn´t follow wit the current Google API environment.

The promise I was given when I bought the course wasn´t delivered. This is not enough for me to create my own website or project.

All this said I also need to leave some comments of the positives of this course. First of all the Q&A team. I've asked a couple of things and responses were quick and helpful. On online environment that is very welcome.

The course is thorough. I think I now have the tools to go deeper into the different technologies and languages if I want.

Colt is very clear in his expositions. Some times speaks to quick for a foreigner like myself, but we have the magic of rewind to hear as many times as we wish.

With all considered this is probably, still one of the best and more complete courses online available on the subject. I feel tempted to search for others though.

There are many other positive aspects I haven´t focused on. All in all I think 3 stars is the rate applicable at this point in time.

Colt and team, please think about updating the materials, or even creating a new whole course.

This was a great, comprehensive course to learn the basics of web development! Colt, has a engaging and informative teaching style that gives you a great foundation to go into more advanced topics. It kind of ends abruptly without much guidance on how to proceed, but Colt definitely gives all you need to figure it out. The sky is the limit after you take this course! Thanks Colt, Ian, Zarko, Louli, and Akshay for all your hardwork!

Frustrating is how I would best describe this course. In the beginning course is alright. It just gets incredibly frustrating towards the end where almost everything is outdated. The slides beforehand are always nice - where it mentions the updated syntax, but having to follow through those videos with outdated syntax where we learned the updated syntax many many slides ago is just frustrating, confusing, and just plain annoying. This course was probably great 5 years ago, but these videos need to be updated properly for it to be truly effective. The few slides many moons ago, don't do this course any justice, and the fact that there are often so many things left out of the videos truly leaves me demotivated to finish the course. I always return to finish, but I can see these frustrations leaving many not wanting code again. Decent course for the price, Colt is a pretty good teacher and I would love to learn from him at one of his other bootcamps, but the material is lacking in 2020.
Awesome course for all groups , covered almost everything related to WEB Developer ever needed to learn you have to put your effort first in this course there more than enough to learn !!

The course offers a lot of content! I expected this course to take me from a complete novice to a beginner level web developer and it has. The first half of the course that deals with frontend development is very comprehensive as Colt takes time to explain concepts.

The second half however left me a bit frustrated; the backend development felt more like bringing the puzzle pieces together rather than understanding the basic of puzzle. The course has given me a good idea of how node works, but I am unsatisfied with the approach taken: most of the time, when we included packages, it felt like we were doing so arbitrarily. On this front, there were too many minor things to take care of and remember; I am not sure if this is inherent to working with node, but it was left unclear.

Overall, the course offers more than what I paid for it and I am happy with what I have learned from this course.

Thanks Colt!

Very good introducing me to new technologies in more modern web development. A good fit in general, but given my robust experience in previous statistical programming (and occasional web-app-widget creation) in R and Python I think an advanced course would have been slightly more appropriate.

I would give 10 stars if possible.

One of the best courses I did (and I've done plenty).

The instructions given by Colt are very clear, easy to follow along, and the YelpCamp project is really cool, as it gives us an objective to achieve by the end of the training (I am still working on it after finishing the training, to include more features and put in practice everything I've learned).

Another point that I really appreciated is that all external services (online database, image storage, deploy servers) are free and credit card information is not required.

Lastly, the course was entirely reviewed and updated (in 2020). I was literally in the middle of the old one when the update came, but I gladly went through all of it again.

Thank you very much Colt for this extrordinary experience.

Colt is a great instructor and the course is really complete. One downside, I read before starting it, in some forums, that it's out of date, which is true. BUT, Ian made a great job on keeping it up to date. He added a lot of value to it, not only in the course but also with extra material on his YouTube channel and DevSprout, his personal courses website.

Thanks Colt and Ian for creating an amazing course, keep up the great work!

This course is so good, very detailed, Max teaches you the very basics to the requirements you need to build a SPA! There is also, Jost, Max's assistant who always answer all your questions. Thank you for the course!

This guy is just the best <3 Max will help you understand topics as deep as necessary.

He also has fun verbal comments :D

Basically, this course is great. I split my opinion into 4-star achievement and one star missing.

4-star achievement:

Well organized, most of its content is updated. This course is built in a way that helps the students to practice and internalize the material properly.

However:

One star missing:

There is no proper introduction for RXJS operators such as map, tap, switchMap, and so on.

The Angular-Universal section was very bad explained and not updated.

The last two chapters needed to be presented earlier in this course
Max you are rockstar ! Many are shifting now a days to react but there is a solid reason angular exist's and you have done a great job.

I really love this course. As a web developer, I learned angular for a while, and this is the most clear and nice course I've ever learned.

Also I have to say Maximilian is really awesome, those bonus courses really useful, hope to learn more from him!

Really helpful, thanks to Maximilian provides me this Angular complete guide!!!
Some parts of the course are still using old versions packages, Feels like, he is just changing the Name of the course only. But overall It is a Great course.
This course is a comprehensive compendium of knowledge about Angular. Interesting examples, understandable explanation. I recommend this course.

Request you dont mix regular concept teaching and course project.

Follow only once. Course project can be added as bonus.

As the course is progressing concepts teaching also shifyted to course project. one who dont follow course project they cant understand the advanced topics even if you explain very well.
It was amazing towards the beginning, but as it got towards the bonus material some of the information might have been a bit too compressed.

I do appreciate the effort Max puts into these videos but I feel there is to many references to "there", "here" without clearly showing or saying what "there" and "here" is. Also, in some occasions there is fast scrolling up and down that is next to impossible to track and follow.

To many "of course", "and there", "and then" and explanations sometimes get tangled without any reason. In addition, better structuring the course would help, using git repo that is properly organized to track Max's progress would help rather than downloading zip files.

This is one is indeed ultimate angular course. I am coming from react, and i need angular for my new job. And this is exactly what i have been looking for. I really liked how Max structured the flow of this course so that we get all downsides and features of different approaches in angular. Additional thanks for ssr bonus lectures i learned a lot thanks to them. As always thanks a lot Max. Will be glad to see new courses from you in advance. Take care.
je suis satisfait , malheureusement il n'existe pas une version en français

The way how Angela explained topics is fantastic, at the same time understandable but also very interesting, this is the reason what kept me not only on topics that are new for me but also on topics on which I'm familiar.

This course is one of the best for everyone (beginners, intermediates, advance ), Dr.Angela is a good tutor. This course is well designed, taught and explained. I don't have any idea about coding but this course enlightened me. I have also purchased the ios 13 and swift 5, and the complete 2020 flutter development Bootcamp. Just to tell you how much I enjoyed the way she teaches, explains and solves problems/challenges.

This was an amazing course! I can't say enough good things about this course. Angela is an amazing instructor, and did an extremely great job teaching all that was promised in the course description.

I'm happy "The Complete 2020 Web Development Bootcamp" was my FIRST programming course! I feel confident enough to move onto more specific courses. Thank you Angela!!!!

In this course I get more experiences in web development. If I get down, this course gave you motivation to let you get up again and ready to the new journey. Don't let your dream to be web developer down!

"I got a magic stick from an angel now I think I am ready to use". The magic stick is "The Complete 2020 Web Development Bootcamp" and the angel is "Dr. Angela Yu". You are one of the best teachers in my life, Thank you.

I've completed the course and hands down by far one of the best courses on Udemy ❤ .

It offers all you could expect from a Bootcamp course and more.
This is my first web development course and this course has introduced me to a ton of information that I would definitely use in my career as a software developer and engineer

Angela is an amazing instructor. Explains wonderfully. I've learned so much over the course's time. So many useful information takes a little bit of time to soak in, but Angela does a great job at destructuring it into small pieces so it gets easily received by us. Only the best I can say about this whole experience. Keep it up, Angela!

Este curso desarrollado por Angela es implemente excelente . Su forma de enseñar es muy efectiva. Es una de las mejores instructores que conozco. Felicitaciones a Angela por compartirnos su conocimiento de forma extraordinaria y a Udemy por tenerla como instructora.

This course is absolutely amazing! It is fantastic value for money and easily the best course on the subject that I have found. I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone thinking about learning web development. I didn't write this review until after I had completed all 50+ hours of the course and I can absolutely say that, from beginning to end, it is extraordinary. You'll be a little amazed at what you can do after completing it.
Amazing, during this lockdown period I have managed to cover a lot of e-learning and I will without a doubt be purchasing more content from Angela. Thank you

I learned a lot of new technical stuff and the most importantly I got to know about online resources that Angela refers to and encourages us to use to make web development more productive. Moreover, Angela your are an amazing instructor. I didn't find a single chapter in the whole course boring, thanks to your teaching skills!
It is an amazing course, earlier I didn't have the confidence to work on UI but after this course, I have the confidence that I can build and understand the code that is written by any JS developer.

Awesome course for beginners ,teaches you more than just Javascript,this course teaches you ,what you would do when you actually end up in a Javascript deeveloper job ,all the practical concpets which are used in the companies are taught ,like babel,webpack ,how to setup a localhost, MVC ,HTML DOM manipulation ,ES6 and many such practical real world concepts are covered rather than just the basic syntax of Javascript which you can study from W3schools also,So this is a must do course for a beginner who wants to be a Javascript developer.
Very Awesome !! explained the java script the way a programmer should think and program , very good , i loved it
Yes content is really awesome and way of teaching is very nice. Generally people get bore in short span of time during courses but this is amazing.
Amazing course! Enjoyed making forkify project and in turn learned a whole lot of new concepts in JS.
Thank u so much for this amazing flood of knowledge on the topic, really appreciate ur efforts to make coding a real easy hobby.

I can say this course is may be the best course for JavaScript on Udemy in many aspects. The way Jonas organizes, explains and helps the student to learn is clear and smooth, unlike many course out there. I wish if he can create a new version or even update this course to more JavaScript concepts and make it a Modular complete Guide, because it lacks many aspects especially the advanced ones.

This is a very good course it covers the basics part pretty well. Take note, you really have to slow down on the advance parts specially at Section 5. Also those coding challenges are just a pain in the butt so watch out for those :)
Amazing depth and very good teaching style. Absolutely would recommend it to anyone!

This course get a very high rating from me as it's pretty easy to follow.

This could also be down to the fact that I recently learned python and quite a few of the fundamentals are the same.

Jonas has a great way of teaching. He has very intelligently structured the whole course and indeed, anyone could learn JavaScript, and that too in very less time. He moves to the next topic very smoothly, and intelligently interrelates the previous topic.

Jonas is a great teacher, who explain concepts the best way that you can imagine. Hands up to the teaching assistants who instantly reply to questions. This is a great course that every JS programmer should consider taking!

The experience was good. All the things that i have learned till now are easily understandable and compatible. Would love to make a big project using all this knowledge.

Thank you for sharing such great knowledge.

Very good, simple to understand and follow basic rules of css. By attempting more advanced exercises, if i get stuck then i always come back to this site to follow the ground rules which helps me to understand things better.

This is a decision I shall never regret.

Rob is on point, well explained course.

Although I have no previous coding experience I can now try to build a real website. Thanks rob
I will definitely recommend this course to any beginner web developer or anyone who just want to build solid basic web development understanding

The Course was a great introduction to the many aspects of web development. Rob has picked the right mix of coverage to get someone moving in the directions.

The content and presentation were great!

My suggestions are;

1. Create a course notes that could be used as reference as well as cover the intricacies of some of the area, ex. debugging php, python, and schematic view of arriving at MVC project.

2. The final section "where do you go from here" could include some tips on setting up students own environment for doing web project on their own machines for practice purpose, which includes a webserver and required IDE.

Overall, the course was great to follow and practice. Learnt a lot!!

Regards, Tapan.
I enjoyed the course very much, sometimes out of my depth but perhaps if I keep coding things will become easier.

All in all I have learned some great skills and managed to create a fully fledged website. There are about 3 or 4 places where a note comes up on screen to say that what is being taught is out of date and to do something else, if you aren't looking at the screen at that point in time (if you are working on what is being said at the time for example) you can end up wasting a few hours, perhaps an audio cue could help. Also would advise taking the exams after completing the course and re-visiting each unit, as for me some of the questions in the exams related to later in the course. I would recommend this course if you are a determined person who can problem solve well (which are skills you need for web development anyway), but think the UX could have been better with refreshed/overhauled content.
The main reason I took the course is to add jquery, bootstrap, PHP, APIs, and some python to the other skills that I already have so that I can build a complete website.
The firsts sections were pretty good, but I couldn't learn much after the bootstrap section. After that section, I'd just followed along because I couldn't understand the process anymore.

This was my first purchase on Udemy and I have to say I was impressed. I have prior experience working in web development, so some subjects were easier for me than most. I thought Rob's way of teaching was done very well and would recommend his course to anyone starting out in web development. The instructional videos with quizzes and the community are top notch. Thank you, Rob, for your knowledge and I look forward to some of your courses in the future.

It was an amazing course.I had no prior knowledge related to web development and after completing this course,I am confident to make websites on my own.The explanations where really helpful throughout the course.
I was really pleased with the course and how available the teacher was in the Q&A section. The only thing that was bad in my opinion is that it lacked more challenging quizes related to the sections.
It's an amazingly well organized detailed course. It would be great if this course also adds a way typescript is used in building react applications for the basic libraries used here.
This is a pretty thorough explanation of react. Mr Grider doesn't only help you understand what is happening he also answers the question why.
Stephen has extraordinary talent in both on the subject and on teaching. He went into minute details of each concept and explained. This is definitely one of the best courses on ReactJS.

Excelente explicación para las personas que disfrutan estar como "en una clase" donde hay una ruta pero no se siente robotizado. Excelentes explicaciones con aplicaciones diversas. Sólo sería conveniente mover parte del material antiguo a otro curso para que no fuera necesario verlo/saltarlo

I completed the course except for the legacy parts. This was my first React + Redux course, so I can't compare this to others, but as proven by many other reviews, this was an amazing course. All aspects of react and redux were explained so well I was able to understand the fundamental ideas and advanced knowledge. Also, throughout the course, we built around 10 projects, in which we focused on the react and redux part, not on stylings, which I loved it since we had enough time to discuss all details of react and redux. Thanks so much Stephen and please keep updating the course with the newest content, so that it can be the one top of the React course on Udemy.

In one sentence: this is the best React and Redux course you can find on Udemy. I've purchased more than 10 courses this year. This is the best of the best!! If you can only learn one course on ReactJS, look no far, this is it! Stephen is also the best instructor on web development (actually on computer science, I'd say). The course is super organized. And the pace of the course is very comfortable. You can follow him step by step with no problem. I'll purchase more courses from Stephen for sure! 100000/100 Recommend!!!

Stephen is an experienced teacher. The coarse starts with the basics, requiring almost no prior experience with JS or React, yet quickly and efficiently builds in complexity. The lessons are pragmatic, yet layered with theory and real-world experience; he explains both the right and wrong way of doing things and hammers it in with repetition. It really includes everything, even free-tier hosting to help get your portfolio started. Highly recommended, I look forward to Stephen's other classes!
The best course I have enrolled on Udemy! Stephen explained not only React but also modern Javascript concepts. The sample projects are funny and good for learning.

This course contains really detailed clarification of different React concepts. Moreover, the explanations provided by Stephen contain bonus content gained from his experience. I would only criticize the repetitiveness of few topics which were mentioned throughout the course. Although some of them were focused on different versions of the same library, a few of them were simply repeated too many times for the same version of a given library (at least too many times in my opinion). But overall, an amazing course!
A well detailed react course beyond any I've ever watched. If you want a complete react course, this is the best option I've seen so far.
This course is fantastic! Stephen presents the topics by using diagrams that are super easy to understand and gives the details of each topic in a deep way. I really recommend this course.
course is good, too detailed at times, instructor is good, i would improve it by adding more testing and exercises, also could be of shorter length

This is one of the best HTML5 and CSS3 courses on the Internet.

Jonas is an amazing instructor- He explains all the topics really well together with excellent presentations.

You get to learn valuable knowledge about web development and web design. You'll learn all the theory stuff and then put them into practice on ONE BIG project. After finishing this course, you will understand the process of building a website- from idea/sketch to production.

I loved this course. It dove right in to what you need to learn. It taught you the basics of what you need to know for HTML and CSS so that you can start building your own websites right away. What I recommend is to watch bits and pieces of this course and as soon as you learn it, APPLY IT, that way you can commit what you learned to memory.

Excellent course to gain working knowledge of HTML and CSS. Very detailed, methodical and step-by-step instructions to build a modern, responsive website from scratch. Lot of useful reference site was mentioned. The codinghero site maintained by the author is useful for real-world development. Was extremely happy with the course since it served my purpose. Few tidbits of JS and Jquery was added but it was easy to follow. The final bonus section on flexbox and css grid was not very useful. Few sections are however outdated and might need to be reworked. The ionicons library previously implemented with css no longer work the way it used to. The ionicons are now JS driven. This requires some changes in few sections. Not very difficult changes though.

very excellent course. i got the fuel what i need to star my carrier. but one thing i should mention that when we ask question regarding any problem i didn't get answered regarding my problem. i had to wait for long time. that is frustrating. otherwise this course is very helpful for the beginner students of webdesign.

This course has covered a lot of useful information for HTML5 and CSS3. However, the instructor should improve his ability to speak English better. Also, he should explain carefully every property of programming language for students, not just go through. Need more improvement for this course by careful explainations of everything !!!!!!!

The material is quite dated and if you didn't take this course five years ago you're going to run into a lot of issues. Also, Jonas's assistant is quite lax in responding to inquiries regarding issues that arise. The Q&A section states it takes 48 hours to respond but it doesn't take long to realize that responses are done at his leisure. In fact, it's because of my last few interactions with his assistant that I won't be finishing.

The course is good. At the time of enrollment my target was for HTML5 and CSS3. Lots of area has been covered in a meaningful way. But some of the part like JQuery was not required. As a fair knowledge of JavaScript is required for that. Without that it becomes meaningless. In place of that it would have been good had other areas of HTML and CSS would have covered. Also at many places reference to eBook has been made which has been missing. It has been answered that in place of eBook website URL has been provided. Could not find all things in the website that has been mentioned. Many referenced websites have changed the way of functioning and some of them don’t even exist now. Hope course should have been updated accordingly. But overall happy for it. Only 2 points. 1. Please update where changes have happened. 2. As for this course rather than other topics (like JQuery, PHP), have more area of HTML and CSS covered in it. (This is not in negative sense please).

Thank you for the nice course.

A good course to start into to know about the in and out of html and css if you are just a beginner. It will help you get the feel and idea on how to start coding a website. However, the course might be kind of outdated since some of the things that you will learned will be replaced by a better solution and simpler coding commands or they do simply work but in a redundant way, thus you have to find a better solution by researching yourself or in the Q&A some of the time.
Great to know about the various concepts of web development and clear cut view of how a webpage is developed as per the customer's expectatitons

You Can teach an Old Dog New Tricks!

I was always apprehensive about learning web development in the past.

After trying a small nursery course, ‘as I call it’, Jonas’s course came highly rated and regarded in most Google searches for reviews and advice.

Those great ratings were not wrong either. This course is absolutely fantastic.

I love the sections on responsive design for Mobile Phones & Tablets.

So pleased I chose this course to start me on my way.

This old dog, (myself), is a 55 year old who should have studied this subject years ago.

Highly recommend this to anyone starting out from scratch.

I am now hooked on every element of the subject and very grateful too.

Bravo and Thanks,

Fraser.
Very Informative and learnt a lot, overwelming at times if new to this but Jonas does a good job to make this course as easy as possible to follow. Thanks!

The course is understandable, if you do not have experience like me in HTML, CSs and jS this course will help you understand the basic principles. The only problem is that the course is outdated and that makes you feel frustrated because you are wasted a lot of time trying to solve the problems caused by this outdated course.

Je ne peux que recommander ce cours : tant sur le fond que sur la forme.

Maximilian est très compréhensible et son cours est très complet : au niveau théorique c'est parfait, mais les occasions de mettre les connaissances en pratique ne manquent pas.

Holy moly, I really thought I need to brush up when Vue 3 is released. But Max updated the course... for FREE!

This is top-notch education right here!
¡Excelente curso, excelente instructor! Se nota muchísimo la experiencia y conocimiento del instructor, sabe explicar de forma clara y precisa.
Your efforts are incredible. Thanks

Maximilian Schwarzmüller is a great teacher to learn. He has amazing knowledge about Web Development and next-gen technologies in Software Development.

His course is easy to understand and catch up not only by his deep knowledge but also explaining very mindfully.

Despite of some lessons is confused to me, it is not a big deal. I can still handle in my company projects

This course is excellent! It coveres Vue.js theory in full. Information in all modules is well explained and structured. Though some videos should be updated so to keep the course up to date from the very beginning.

Max is really a great, skilled and experienced instructor explaining everything in a very detailed and understandable way! Thanks! :)

Mr. S is an absolutely amazing teacher. He goes in depth into even the smallest details and delves deep into the information, all while keeping the topics interesting and and the lectures engaging. 5/5 stars for sure. PS. His accent is also super cool.

As the title of the course already says: it is a very complete dive into Vue. The sections are split up into small and easy to follow lectures. Every section is accompanied by good example applications and one big application that can be very useful as a reference project.

I bought this course a few days before the Vue 3 content was released which was added to the same course.

Max explain the material with great patience and detail.

This course is very professional and deserves only 5 starts!! no less :)
easy understanding, great mentor, gud exercises, useful assignments, and a good start for beginners
Very in depth look at Vue 2/3 a as well as Vue Router and Vuex. I love how the course was updated as soon as Vue 3 was released.

In the updated course I miss the assignments with each lecture. All the explanations are to the point and well structured. Just as a side note, do not expect Max to teach you everything, try and do stuff on your own!

I genuinely and whole heartedly cannot explain just how good this course actually is. I dived in head first, completely unsure on what to expect AND with zero experience of programming. Four weeks later, I emerge the other side, not only blown away by how amazing the content was, but with the confidence to create my own web applications. I honestly don't think I can describe just how worthwhile this course is. I'm already signing up for the senior dev course. Thank you, Andrei and Wolfgang.

It a good course that touches almost all the fields that is required to be a professional web developer. This course will not give you complete knowledge about everything that is required by the employers, but it will show you the path to reach your destination.

this course can change my whole life. so many question i have before purchase this course but at the end i found so much valuable skills that so much expensive than what we pay .

Andrew are really really number one Teacher . Thank you so much

Great course that covers all the topics you will need to grasp to get into the world of web development. Great instructor that knows how to teach so that we as the students can take out from it as much as we can!!! <3

This is not only great course! This is much more: wide society that helps, perfect support, a lot of non-technical information about IT field (so important when you start). It learned how to solve problems not only how to followed the content.

A lot of time, but it worth every minutes.

Thanks a lot!
The best course to understand how the internet and web applications work, without a doubt Andrei is the best teacher I have known throughout this wonderful world of web development.

I personally loved the course, the only downside is HEROKU. Not That Heroku is not Good. But there more efficient and DIFFERENT Cloud Services Like AWS and GCP which should have been taught in the Project. Heroku was so damn simple that I didn't need the tutorial.

Thank you Andrei and team for this amazing course! I can say this is more than an introduction to web development. It covers a lot that I think it is gearing towards the advanced stage which is great! I won't lie that there were concepts that I don't grasp at first but it taught me to do some work on my own like checking documentations, searching google/stackoverflow to better understand them. Highly recommended!

I cannot be more happier that I bought this course, as well as finished it! I like the way Andrei teaches, except had some issues with PostgreSQL, as I was using Windows (would not like to use it on this OS). Detalized, yet still challenging, as so many useful and interesting resources for finding out myself the issues or just reading and learning! Thank you!

I liked the course alot, Andrei is a good teacher but what i didnt liked he is never there to help students and students cant help other students in advanced things as they are also students . One more things I didnt liked that he attach articles all the time in his videos and always says that read from attached article. He should discuss in details those things as students comes from different background which is not programming. overall Andrei has a very good knowledge no doubt on it . But he should changed his way of teaching a bit.
while going through the course it feels like i am in one-to-one training, the way you teach is absolutely amazing! Thank you so much Andrei.

In-depth explanation of course topics. Focuses on the recent and most used skills needed to become a full-stack web developer. Provides a community to connect with other students and open-source projects.

You are a very good teacher that you can explain difficult concepts very well. Appreciate your effort to make animation to illustrate some of the concepts. very mush worth for time, I would highly recommend this course, Amazing course, with a lot of aha moments, as Tony says.

I didn't go for five stars though because there are some areas that I thought were badly explained and I had to go elsewhere for a lot of information (particularly around what prototypes actually are and how promises actually work). Also, it seems that so much of JS is passing parameters into functions, and defining those parameters using arguments wherever that function is called. This distinction between parameters and arguments never actually gets explained on this course: you have to figure it out for yourself. The final two projects were EXTREMELY well explained, and it would have been great if the whole course was explained to this level. Overall though, I'm really happy with what I got out of it.

Positives:

This course is pretty extensive in terms of the number of topics covered.

Support provided for this course is pretty decent.

I like Brad's code along approach, because if you write even 10 lines of code just to test out a concept (and save it), then you are more likely to remember it and you can always come back to it for revisions.

Weaknesses:

Too many loose ends, too much googling and mdn browsing in a course i paid for.

Small errors in explanation here and there can lead to hours (in one case days) wasted on googling

Whats more, Brad very cunningly tiptoes past the topics he wouldn't or couldn't explain like closures. Yeah a JavaScript course without a mention of closures.

No word about apply, bind or call functions.

He used filter function late in lecture 98 in a wrong manner which just by luck worked for the example he was working on. So cannot even expect the explanation there.

Incomplete coverage of the the spread operator.

For...of loop (without any introduction) was used for the first time in the lecture on sets in section 10.

In the last section, he just tells to download the webpack+babel setup from his GitHub profile without explaining how he created it.

The list is too long.

I struggled learning Javascript coming from a career with no programming skills needed or experience. The focus was mainly on just how to write functions, arrays, and objects and not seeing any results of this outside of logging things on a console. These lessons for the first time showed me how JS can manipulate the DOM, methods for targeting HTML in a webpage, creating OOP, modules, patterns, and lots more so I finally could see what JS was doing when related to working on webpages for front-end work. The small projects are super helpful, and helped me to really understand the language while both coming together and in the final product. I will definitely be revisiting these videos for practice and test how much more I can do independently as I progress.

ALSO- I would recommend grabbing the latest version of the course for iOS 13 if you can, because some things are out of date in this course.

Other than that, I have no complaints. Angela is truly awesome and if you have the discipline to get through the course, you will learn a ton even in the first 20 hours. My only other wish is that there would be some bonus lectures on NFC encoding but I can understand why its omitted since you need an iPhone X or later plus NFC cards/wristbands to read and write NFC with an app.

The course is really good! But with "but"s.

+ The content of this course is VERY big, valuable, lots of useful techniques, unobvious approaches, Android lifehacks and design tricks.

+ Jean-Paul usually replies questions very fast and this is a great support!

+ Tim speaks on video with optimal speed: many lecturers speek too slow and make course too long, not in this case. This means, more information is packed in these 60 hours of lectures.

- MANY times I was like, "what`s going on?" because the explanation style is: "coding on screen, telling what the code does". This is master class, yes, not a definitive course of lectures, but more visual material (e.g. illustrating how different parts of Android ecosystem work) would be of great help. Tables with app structure helped a lot, but there are just a few of them.

- Course has a cliffhanger "we will make app settings in the next video" and there`s no next video, it is the end of the course. (as of 31.07.2020). I hope it will be finished.

Conclusion: I would recommend this course to any person who is gonna be Android developer, though not as a first, "introduction" course.

2 months ago

I want to start by saying I have always been good at analytical thought processing. I was always good at math, so while I'm new to programming it's not something I find to be inherently difficult or abstract. Also, I have gotten through most of this course already so it's not like I started a few videos, didn't like them, and quit. I've been pushing through and intend to finish the course but at this point I can see that certain things are not going to change towards the end.

The structure of this course is just horrible. Apparently they are working on a revision which I believe should help to some degree as it became blatantly obvious when I got past the revised portion and into the original course material.

The first problem I have with the structure is that there is very little thought put into prioritization. It seems like there is just as much time and emphasis put on things that are trivial as there is on the core concepts that you are trying to learn. For instance, he literally spends about 1.5 hours on time zones. If I want to become an expert on time zones I can look that up on my own time. I'm trying to learn programming here, sure time zones are a valuable thing to know how to implement, but they are hardly essential to the main goal of learning how to program.

Second, there is not very much drilling of core concepts. There are really no big projects that help you to put what you learn into practice. Other courses I've taken in Javascript, HTML/CSS, have had projects along the way so you get comfortable with what you've learned so far before moving on.

Third, this seems like almost as much of a trouble shooting class as a teaching class. I understand that trouble shooting is VERY important in programming. However, the lessons are so often interrupted with trouble shooting tips that you kind of lose focus on the main reason most people take the class, learning to do things correctly. This is probably a feature that may be beneficial to people who are intermediate Python programmers, but for those of us who are beginners as the course advertises it is meant for, the trouble shooting really can be distracting from just learning the correct ways of doing things. Might be beneficial to have a separate trouble shooting section at the end of the course instead of constantly interrupting the study flow of students showing them how to deal with this and that along the way that really shouldn't be happening if they are writing their code correctly. Usually this occurs in the middle of a video, but sometimes is just inserted into a section as a random separate video that is not necessarily just applicable to that sections material. For instance, halfway through the SQL/Database section we just stop and get into 1.5 hours worth of videos about exception handling. I get that exception handling is applicable to SQL/databases, but it is far from being exclusively applicable to that area of Python, so why stop in the middle of SQL/databases, why not just add it in it's own section or at least at the beginning or end of the database section instead of stopping right in the middle?

Fourth, trial and error. I get that programming entails a lot of trial and error, however, when you're new at something you'll make enough typos and other errors all on your own. These videos were made seemingly with little prior plan for how goals would be achieved. The instructor seems to be processing how he's going to do things as he does them. This leads to students sometimes being told to type code that doesn't execute correctly and then having to adjust it along with the instructor after they've already spent time typing a bunch of stuff out. Also a lot of things that may not necessarily cause code not to execute but that the instructor tells you to do it one way and then halfway through just realizes that the way he had done it is not the best way to do it and has you change it.

Fifth, similar names. Throughout the course the instructor will use a similar names for multiple things in a video or even the same name with the only difference being one start with a capitalized letter and one without or one is plural and one is not, etc etc. This makes in difficult to follow what is supposed to be going where as you're writing code. Am I referring to a class or a variable? etc, etc. It also makes it less obvious what previously written code is referring to as you're watching the video, is this code referring back to the Class, to a variable, to a function? May seem obvious to an intermediate student but to a beginner it makes the learning process more difficult. It also makes it unnecessarily difficult to catch errors when your code doesn't execute properly.

Finally, too much going on in a single video. To be fair, this does seem to be something they are addressing in the up coming revised version. But very often in this course you will be working on a concept, you'll learn how to do it, and then rather than leaving that video finished and having that in your mind as to how that concept/process should be done, he'll continue the video and have you erase what you've done to show you another way of doing it, and then another way of doing it, and then another way of doing it. By the end you're kind of like "what the hell was I supposed to be learning to begin with?". Probably better to just start a new video, create a new file, copy the code from the other file, and then change it to learn another variation of how to do something. It would help with keeping different concepts/processes separate in your mind.

Overall I think this course is difficult and frustrating for a beginner to follow. I would imagine that it would not be as difficult for an intermediate student to follow, but might still be just as frustrating.

This course is not what I expected at all. Yes, Max does in fact cover all the necessary topics that he says that he will cover, but when it came to getting unstuck it was hard not to be disastisfied with the lack of answers provided by the teaching assistants. There are also problems that prior students pointed out 2-3 years ago that were NEVER corrected in the module. So you have students in 2020 still running into issues that students in 2017 told Max and Adam to update years ago. While the TA is why I paid for the course(just the ability to get some feedback), responses to problems were pretty much consistent, "use my source code", "have you compared your source code to my code" and was no really help at all. I stopped coding a month ago because I was stuck on an issue that I couldn't solve in the lecture, I came back and see that new tickets have been added to the Q&A resource tab - looks like this problem has STILL not been resolved. You even have prior students telling Max and Adam that the module should be updated to reflect the answers they have found after hours and hours of extensive troubleshooting. So there are sections where students can easily be guided but no guidance has been provided. But I guess we should all be thankful that DenoJS has just been added to the course. How about fixing the bugs/really taking a look at what students are having issues/reteaching some of the areas that are problematic and then focus on pushing out new content? It must be a slap in the face for students to spend hours and hours of debugging and coming up with solutions only for Max to add new content, but never address the bugs and problems in the module or the code. I also didn't like the constant refactoring. If I was stuck in one section, it made it harder to determine where the problem was because Max had already started on a new topic in A NEW SECTION. The course comes out super disorganized, and I cannot image that I put in wayyyy too much time into this course thinking that it was going to change somehow. The amount of hours that's needed in the course doesn't make sense when it can be taught rather simply and straightforward. There were also some sections that a quick Google search provided clear and succint answers to that Max explained in a rather difficult way.

It was a nice journey of almost 6 moths( Includes practice time ), I learned a lot about node and some other relatively important topics.

I do have one important complaint and that is regarding working with the H2o platform in the ANN lecture. There are many, many complaints on this topic which have not been addressed by the author(s). I came to the solution after much research and it involves installing a compatible version of Java JDK on your machine. The documentation is found on the H2o website. As of today, H2o does not support the most recent version of Java (15) so you will need to download an earlier version from the Java archive. Installing/uninstalling is a bit of a pain, but good luck.

So I just finished this course today. The lecture contents was long and exhaustive. I can tell the instructors had put in a lot of efforts and time to make the lectures interesting. The total hours for this course is 29 hours, and i think it took me like 60 hours due to stopping, replaying, stopping again, and taking notes etc. Overall, I think they could have done better. Some suggestions I think this course could improve on:

1. python - when you introduce the codes there should have been some markups with arrows and bullet points stating what that code does and when you run the code show us with markings what it does. Most of the time the instructor will get overly excited when he runs the code and not explaining what's going on. Also when you add a code, to add some columns show us where it will end up and mark them on the videos. More bullet point notes the better. Sometimes you introduce new codes and don't exactly explain what it does and it gets so confusing. And you also copy and paste codes from somewhere and expect us to understand what you did as it went over my head. Because this Python part is so important to all of us learning for the first time, and eventually we'll get into Data Science in our careers one day, this section needs to be improved on so we all can better understand what's going on.

2. TF1 vs TF2 - I don't think there's any need to go comparing both of these as TF2 is current and mostly what we are trying to learn now right? Also getting TF2 to install was a nightmare as some people had the same issue.

3. Intro. to the field of Data Science - These lectures are way too long. You have 8 sections describing this and could have sum up in a few lectures stating what it does and the types of careers one can go into with the type of skill sets. Sorry but I was about to fall asleep.

4. Mathematics - Maybe need to add basic Calculus

5. Probability and Stats - it was long but alright.

6. Other items to add - SQL and Big Data, just the basic stuffs and how to integrate these into Python, and discuss what software we'll need to learn etc.

7. Lecture Videos - Quality could be better as the video seems a bit blurry or low quality.

8. Instructors - As most students stated that the instructors voice sounded like a robot and not a real human teaching and I totally agree. I won't drill into too much but I find the instructor who was teaching the Case Study for the Absenteeism (Preprocessing) does a good job as he uses markups to indicate how the code was executed and carried out.

I did enjoyed it and learned some skills along the way. Thanks.

This course provides a great breadth of coverage on data science concepts, including peripheral topics seldom covered elsewhere (e.g. hyperparameter tuning, ethics and handling missing data). In terms of suggestions for improving the course further, here are a couple of areas for suggested inclusion:

- model explainability for scenarios where dimensionality reduction is utilised (e.g. PCA) or emergent behaviour is observed (e.g. deep learning). This is because explaining how a model arrived at a particular prediction is a critical topic for gaining business confidence from a product owner/business stakeholder.

- when multiple models are feasible to address a business problem, which considerations determine model selection (unless the recommendation is to try all feasible models and use the model that provides the best results, similar to the final project's approach).

- model drift, the factors that cause it, and how to address it (e.g. model retraining)

As a suggestion for an advanced follow-up course, it'd be great to be able to explore the underlying mathematical theory of the machine/deep learning algorithms explored in this course. This is something I haven't yet seen elsewhere on Udemy, except for regression models.

A separate more Deep Learning course would also be beneficial for exploring topics such as how different gradient descent optimisation algorithms work and considerations for when each kind of algorithm should be used.

This is a good course. The theory part is especially very good and the tutor exactly knows what he is doing. The first AI, to build the self-driving car, was quite a difficult one to start with, considering no experience in the field. But eventually, you'll get along. The second one, Doom, was absolutely awesome and that is the one I enjoyed the most. That feeling when I saw my AI beat Doom is unexplainable :D. The third one, Breakout, is way too difficult, even the tutor mentioned that it is a bonus.

One feedback I'd like to give is that u could include a small intro to Pytorch and the functions of the same used to make the AIs in the course. Since this course has no requirements (but actually requires knowing PyTorch basics), the above could have been included.

And explaining the structure of the AI beforehand dramatically before moving on to coding can make the coding part more intuitive, especially when starting off and not having any idea of what's ahead.

And this course has a good support team. Never had to wait for more than a day for a reply. There are many topics that more than 20 people are equally doubtful about, so rather than asking the same question again and replying for the same, I'd recommend including the same in the course.

Nevertheless, the course was good overall. I took this course as a starter, and now I know the key areas I have to focus on to get a strong foundation in the field. And can boast about making an AI beat Doom. :D

Had lot of takeway from this course. Thank you guys!!..The way theory and coding part explained was understand-full.

Highlight part was "A3C" you guys made it very simple to understand. Thanks again!..

Course is a good intro to Spark, its like Spark 101. Following are my suggestions to make it even better:

1. Spend more time on Dataframe, Spark SQL

2. A couple of real life project where Spark makes a difference. Projects where one uses both RDD & Dataframe

3. Focus on concepts such as SparkSession vs SparkContext and speak about how in Spark 2.0 SparkSession is used and SparkContext is deprecated

This is a nice course and it brings up grounded approaches and good practices.

What it lacks is depth and practical usage.

For the first, as an example you can easily get multiple times into notation that neural networks of course are better in all parameters than what is being studied here, but you go ahead study it yourself or purchase one more course from the author ))). Sometimes it is even funny

As for the practical usage, it is nice to put hands on deep learning libraries interface, but it would be much nicer to really build couple of applications that perform the real world action. To start with some model, to improve results by changing model and/or approach, to achieve really good scores and make something working. Here you basically make some that works normal at most, stop at the model selection level and get recommendation to improve it somehow yourself. Ok, not problem. But maybe there should be some benchmarking from author? Maybe exercises shall not be at the beginning, like now "Code everything yourself after theoretical part, you shall do that", but after practical part, like "Now your got your hands on code, so make it better in this and this way and we see later how you performed"

Also, it is annoying when source code is updated, but video is not. So when you try to code with author you almost always run into simple errors just because a lot of stuff has changed since than, I mean the sintax. So, the options are to spend time checking libraries' docs to fix the error or to look the source code, which is not nice.

I give the ratting after full course complication. Some basic are defined very well. but if you are look ML that course not for that. E.g. segmentation and lemmatization defined only in 3 minute video. sentiment deduction defined only for single words.

actually i thought of something in mind, but its different then, i just looking for a machine learning basics. this more than that. thank you. i learned something. thank you for answering my question too.

A very good course. Very informative that take you through the different aspects of data science and its Techniques, Tools in details. I really thank David for this course it turned out to be a best kick off course to understand the data science.

This is a great course. I have learned a lot in this course and Rick explains things clearly as well as Ben being helpful too. Even though Rick is using 2017/2018 version of Unity and in 2020 version there are some things have changed, you can find most of the answers in the question area and Nina (Teaching Assistant) has been very helpful in answering questions. I am sure I will be back here to recap now and then. Looking forward to Rick's and Ben's 3D course now.

It has some nice basis, I think some tools could be explained some more, but in general it is a very good course to start, preferably if you have some training in programming.
